sentences.sentence: This was very surprising praise, and completely opposite( 与...相反的 ) to her ideas( 想法 ).
She had previously held a very firm opinion that Mr. Darcy was not a good-tempered man.
“There are very few people of whom that can be said.
You are lucky to have such a master,” said Elizabeth’s uncle.
“Yes, Sir, I am.
He is always very kind to his servants, to his tenants( 房客 ), and to the poor—not like the wild young men nowadays, who think of nothing but themselves.
Some people have called him proud, but I think they have misunderstood him—it is only that he is not naturally a very talkative( 健谈的 ) man.”
“This fine account of him,” whispered her aunt as they walked along, “is not very consistent( 一致的 ) with the way he treated Wickham.”
“Possibly we were deceived( 被欺骗 ) about that—we do not know all the details( 细节 ),” Elizabeth replied.
She reflected on how reliable( 可信的 ) the praise of an intelligent servant such as Mrs. Reynolds must be.
As a brother, a landlord( 地主 ), as a master, how many people depended on Mr. Darcy for their happiness, and how well did he seem to have fulfilled( 履行 ) his responsibilities( 责任 )!
She returned to look at Mr. Darcy’s picture with a kinder and gentler feeling toward its owner than she had ever felt so far.
When they had seen all of the house, they returned downstairs( 楼下 ).
Leaving behind the housekeeper( 管家 ), they were now to follow the gardener, who met them at the hall-door.
As they walked across the grounds toward the river, Elizabeth turned back to look at the house again.
It was just at that moment that the owner of Pemberley himself suddenly came forward from behind the stables( 马厩 ).
They were twenty yards apart, and he had appeared so abruptly( 突然地 ) that it was impossible to hide from him.
Their eyes instantly met, and the cheeks of both turned red with the deepest blush( 脸红的 ).
He was absolutely( 完全地 ) shocked, and for a moment seemed frozen by surprise.
After quickly recovering himself, he moved toward them, and spoke to Elizabeth.
She had instinctively( 本能地 ) turned away, but still she felt an uncontrollable degree of embarrassment( 尴尬 ).
She hardly dared to lift her eyes to his face, and did not know how to respond to his questions about her family.
Nor did he seem much more at ease than she was: he kept stammering( 结巴 ) and repeating himself until he ran out of ideas( 想法 ),
and then after standing for a few moments without saying a word, he suddenly said goodbye.
They had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of the water, but it took quite some time before Elizabeth was aware of any of it.
All she could think of was that one spot in Pemberley House, whichever one it was, where Mr. Darcy might be at that moment.
She longed to know what he might be thinking at that moment, and whether or not, despite everything that had happened, he might still care for her.
While continuing to wander on in this slow manner, they were again surprised by the sight of Mr. Darcy approaching them.
Mrs. Gardiner was a little behind Elizabeth, and Darcy asked Elizabeth if she would do him the honor of introducing her friends( 朋友 ).
This was a polite request for which she was quite unprepared.
When she thought about his previous comments regarding her family’s inferiority( 低等 ), she could hardly keep from smiling that he was now asking for an introduction to exactly that same family.
“How surprised will he be,” she thought, “when he finds out who they are? He currently sees them as fashionable( 上流的 ) people.”
The conversation soon turned to the topic of fishing, and she was amazed( 吃惊的 ) to hear Mr. Darcy invite Mr. Gardiner to fish at Pemberley as often as he liked.
Mrs. Gardiner, who was walking arm-in-arm with Elizabeth, gave her a look of expressive( 意味深长的 ) wonder.
Elizabeth said nothing, but this gave her great satisfaction, because there was no other way to consider this invitation than as a great compliment( 赞美 ) to herself.
Her astonishment( 吃惊 ), however, was very great, and she continually kept repeating to herself, “Why has he changed so greatly?
It cannot be for my sake( 理由 ) alone.
It is impossible that he could still love me.”
After walking some time in this way, Mrs. Gardiner left Elizabeth’s side to walk beside her husband.
Mr. Darcy took her place by Elizabeth, and they walked along together.
Elizabeth broke the silence first,
telling him that she wanted him to know that she had been told he would not be home, before she had agreed to come to Pemberley.
He said that he had been forced to come home on urgent( 紧急的 ) business before he was expected, and thus had arrived a few hours before the people he was traveling with.
“They will join me early tomorrow,” he continued, “and among them are some people you know—Mr. Bingley and his sisters.”
“There is also one other person among them,” he continued after a pause, “who greatly wants to meet you.
Will you allow me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to you during your stay at Lambton?”
She felt such great surprise at this request.
It showed her that, despite all that had happened, he still did not think poorly of her.
He then asked her to sit with him in the house, but she said she did not feel tired, and so they stood together on the lawn( 草坪 ) waiting for Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner.
They said goodbye to one another with the utmost( 极度的 ) politeness.
Mr. Darcy then walked the ladies to the carriage, and when it drove away, Elizabeth saw him walking slowly toward the house.
The day had been far too interesting for Elizabeth to be able to focus on anything else.
For their entire journey back, she could do nothing but think, and think with amazement( 惊讶 ), about how polite Mr. Darcy had been.

article_info.previous: Elizabeth没有阻止成Lydia去Brighton，不久Elizabeth也收到了她的旅行将被缩短的通知，旅途中舅舅和舅母想去Pemberley拜访，而起初Elizabeth不太情愿，因为她害怕碰到Mr. Darcy。在Pemberley，Elizabeth被如诗如画的自然美景所陶醉，也听到了管家对Mr. Darcy的赞扬。
article_info.share_words: Their eyes instantly met, and the cheeks of both turned red with the deepest blush.

question.cn: 为什么Elizabeth对管家的话感到惊讶？
question.en: Why was Elizabeth surprised about the housekeeper's words about Mr.Darcy?

options.cn: 因为管家说Mr. Darcy脾气不好。
options.en: Because housekeeper said that Mr. Darcy was bad-tempered.

options.cn: 因为这些话和她的想法完全相反。
options.en: Because the words were completely opposite to her ideas of Mr. Darcy.

options.cn: 因为管家告诉Elizabeth关于Mr. Darcy孩子的事。
options.en: Because the housekeeper told Elizabeth of Mr. Darcy’s children.

analysis: 文中提到：“This was very surprising praise, and completely opposite to her ideas. She had previously held a very firm opinion that Mr. Darcy was not a good-tempered man.” 所以选B。

question.cn: Mr. Darcy在Pemberley看见Elizabeth时心情是怎么样的？
question.en: How did Mr. Darcy feel when he saw Elizabeth in Pemberley?

analysis: 文中提到：“ He was absolutely shocked and for a moment seemed frozen by surprise.”由此可知选择A。

question.cn: Mr. Darcy以怎样的方式接待Gardiner一家的？
question.en: How did Mr. Darcy treat Elizabeth's family: the Gardiners?

analysis: 文中提到：“……she could do nothing but think, and think with amazement, about how polite Mr. Darcy had been.”由此可知选择B。
